awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Friction Stir Joining of Bulk Metallic Glasses and Their Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
Bulk metallic glasses are a relatively new class of engineering materials with a combination of exceptional properties and unique processing ability. Their high strength, elasticity, corrosion resistance and soft magnetic properties make them attractive for a range of military, medical, sporting, and industrial applications. However, joining of metallic glasses remains a major challenge across multiple length-scales. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research will use a solid-state joining approach to achieve large sections of bulk metallic glasses with superior surface properties. Use of these structures as bio-implants could potentially lessen the likelihood of tissue inflammation, bone deterioration and replacement surgeries thus advancing national health and welfare. Use of stacked metallic glasses as penetrator shields on armor vehicles and spacecraft protection against orbital debris impacts will significantly advance the national defense interests. The proposed project will be collaborative in many aspects, with active engagement between the academic and industrial partners, including an industry internship for two graduate students funded by the project. It will provide a rare opportunity for students to integrate classroom concepts with industrial research and development. The project will engage students from underrepresented groups and will contribute to educating the next generation of scientists/engineers in advanced manufacturing. The project will also benefit society by exposing K-12 students and teachers to emerging areas in science and technology.

The research objective of this GOALI project is to achieve fundamental scientific understanding of friction stir joining process for amorphous metallic alloys and their composites by an integrated experimental and modeling approach. The research project will build on promising preliminary experiments to connect the understanding of material flow in adjoining layers during friction stir joining process, multi-scale deformation behavior, molecular dynamics simulations, and large-scale finite element modeling. The unique and fundamental scientific contributions resulting from the proposed work will be four fold. Firstly, the research will advance knowledge of shear mixing and metallurgical bond formation during high strain processing of amorphous metals and composites. Secondly, it will enable understanding of deformation mechanisms resulting from the interaction of different microstructural features. Third part involving atomistic-scale models will create knowhow on free volume evolution in response to high strain. Lastly, the proposed research will help in the development of a framework to predict location specific properties consisting of spatially resolved structure evolution from the temperature, cooling rate, and strain distribution. The main innovation of the proposed research lies in achieving homogeneous and stacked structures of amorphous metals that are unattainable using existing technologies with the hypothesis that intense shear mixing at the interface between amorphous metallic components ruptures the surface oxide resulting in pristine metal flow and metallurgical bonding. The high strain during processing is expected to increase atomic-scale inhomogeneity in metallic glasses leading to rejuvenation and markedly improved mechanical properties compared to cast amorphous structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Next generation alloys are needed for significant improvements in efficiency, durability, and resilience of structural components in a wide variety of applications ranging from space travel to nuclear fusion and bioimplants. Metallic glasses or amorphous alloys represent a relatively new class of structural materials with exceptional properties and thermoplastic processing ability unlike any other class of known materials. They have ultra-high strength and hardness, excellent corrosion resistance, and soft magnetism which make them attractive in a wide range of industrial and biomedical applications. However, joining of metallic glasses to make large-scale and commercially viable components remains a major challenge. The current project was aimed at overcoming the technical barriers associated with joining of amorphous alloys using friction stir process and fundamental scientific understanding of shear mixing and metallurgical bond formation in metallic glasses. Scalable and facile approaches were used for the synthesis of a wide range of model metallic glasses, ranging from those containing all metallic constituents to metal-metalloid based amorphous alloys. Severe surface deformation processes were studied for metallic glasses and their composites in terms of the evolution in free volume and other defects. The resulting mechanical properties were mapped at the microstructural length-scales because of the systematic variation in thermal and mechanical stress states. Molecular modeling and density functional theory calculations helped in understanding of synergistic effects between the alloy constituents that result in medium and short-range order. The integrated approach of systematic experiments, microstructural and mechanical characterization, and computational efforts helped in detailed understanding of severe surface deformation mechanisms in amorphous alloys. The project provided training and professional growth opportunities for students at a minority serving tier-1 research university. Students from underrepresented minority groups got exposure to topics in advanced manufacturing, metallurgical and materials science, and state-of-the-art characterization. The scientific accomplishments of the project were disseminated to a broad audience in the form of high impact-factor journal publications, conference presentations, and online resources. Several project participants worked with industry partners to gain real world experience beyond their academic program. To encourage K-12 students to pursue careers in science and engineering, the principal investigator arranged workshops and outreach programs on advanced manufacturing in local schools.


Last Modified: 09/05/2024
Modified by: Sundeep Mukherjee
